item.title: Badges: Workplace Edition
item.dc:creator: timmer
item.description: The other day I was trying to think of a way to “spice up” the workplace a little bit. So I took a page out of the Boy/Girl Scouts and Foursquare and created some badges for anyone who knows what it’s like to punch in, plug away at a desk for 8hrs a day, and [...]
item.content:encoded:
The other day I was trying to think of a way to “spice up” the workplace a little bit. So I took a page out of the Boy/Girl Scouts and Foursquare and created some badges for anyone who knows what it’s like to punch in, plug away at a desk for 8hrs a day, and  then punch out.

Below are several badges that I’ve thought up. Each is titled, along with information on how to unlock them. Click on the image to be directed to larger image which you can then printout, laminate, and display proudly as a non-violent way to stick it to the man.

Make sure to inform anyone else you know with a 9-5 so that they can play along too. This is a self-regulating game, so don’t go gloating about badges you didn’t unlock, BECAUSE, TRUST ME, WE’LL ALL F###ING KNOW.

Good luck.

Beat the Clock

“Clock in” at or before the start of the work day for an entire week. Can be strung together for a badge streak earning the designation x2, x3, x4, etc.

Words with Frenemies

Beat a co-worker in a game of Words With Friends 5 consecutive times.

Sleep Working

Take a paid 30 minute uninterrupted nap at your desk (Lunch break DOES NOT count)

Fly Swatter

Repel the advances of at least 5 co-workers (Superiors count as 2 co-workers, interns 0.5 co-workers)

Mad Men

Achieve a “buzz” while on lunch break and finish your workday without being suspected of being slightly inebriated.

Virality

Show 3 viral Youtube videos that no one in the office has seen. Must be completed in one work week (week cannot carry over weekend)

Just Did It

Hook up with some who has unlocked The Fly Swatter Badge.

*Special Note: You cannot obtain the Just Did It Badge if you have unlocked the The Fly Swatter Badge.

The Office Sleuth

Correctly identify the person(s) stealing lunches from the common fridge

Crop Duster

Break wind upon the start of a meeting without being caught.

Rumor Mill

Start a rumor at the workplace that cannot be traced back to you. Completed once you are told said rumor by another co-worker. 8 hours to unlock once rumor has started.

Honey Badger

Special: Can only be unlocked on Friday.

For the last 3 hours of work you must do absolutely no work. No other badges can be unlocked while attempting obtain the Honey Badger Badge.

Do you have any badge ideas?

Hit the comments below and if I get enough / good ideas I’ll illustrate another round. I’ll even give you credit. Or if you don’t want to ruin the surprise, get a hold of me by email: timotimb@gmail.com or by Twitter @timmer_o.

item.title: Desert life
item.dc:creator: amaryllislog
item.description: Sometimes it’s hard to figure out where to start when you have too many photos…you know me…way too many photos. We took a nice little break to Palm Springs this past week with a stop to one of my favorite National Parks, Joshua Tree. JT is the perfect desert for everyone! Seriously, there is so [...]
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes it’s hard to figure out where to start when you have too many photos…you know me…way too many photos.

We took a nice little break to Palm Springs this past week with a stop to one of my favorite National Parks, Joshua Tree. JT is the perfect desert for everyone! Seriously, there is so much to see and great hiking trails plus weird round boulders all over, it’s great and about a hour from Palm Springs…

Butt rock? maybe…

and awesome skull rock!

 

And the rest are going on Flickr!

item.title: Festivals & Fun
item.dc:creator: violetirisphoto
item.description: Holy guacamole lots has happened. We spent one day in Agra which was enough. When we arrived Amit picked up a man who claimed he would be our tour guide in the city then said he cost money. We were caught off guard and sort of let it be then we told him we wanted [...]
item.content:encoded:
Holy guacamole lots has happened.

We spent one day in Agra which was enough. When we arrived Amit picked up a man who claimed he would be our tour guide in the city then said he cost money. We were caught off guard and sort of let it be then we told him we wanted to go somewhere local for lunch but, surprise surprise, we ended up at some western restaurant with high prices that no doubt he got commission for. The son of a gun had swindle us. I snapped. I sat at lunch frowning and fueled with anger unable to be cheered by Maguiver. The only thing that brought a twinkle of joy to my eye was the Navrattan Korma we ordered – a sweeter curry with a mixture of fruits and veg which is now one of our favorite meals here. When it was time to go back out to the car we were both in bad enough moods to be as rude as we could to get our way. It worked. We said piss off to the tour guide slime bag and hello to our first bazaar!! Amit dropped us off down the street and we walked into the most hectic “shopping mall” in the world. Bazaars are roads lined with stools and stands of glittering bangles, heavenly fabrics and assorted homewares. Though the roads were congested with people, we were the only white people and it’s probably the unsafest situation we have been in – we loved it!!! It was Indian culture at its finest. I bought about 30 pretty bangles for $1. As I knelt down to look for the perfect bracelets, hoards of Indians crowded around to watch the white woman find some that actually fit. I made a joke that my hands are too big and the audience giggled.

Just as we thought we were alone we turned around to see another western couple in the same situation as us. After the introduction and a short chat we swapped details with Nicola and Jacob and planned to meet up in Jaipur.

After the bazaar we went to our hotel which was a lovely newer building with a rooftop overlooking the taj mahal. Matt and I sat up there for a while watching the sun go down over the Taj and taking photos of 3 small boys rolling down a dirt pile. In the morning it was time to get up close and personal with the 7th wonder of the world. We lined up for about an hour to get in and missed the sunrise we planned to see – but none the less, when we walked into the gates our breath was taken away. It is as beautiful as you would think – and then some.

After Agra was our 3 hour drive to Jaipur. As we got closer, the scenery began to change and became a lot less flat. We drove through the mountains and arrived in Jaipur. It is surrounded by dusty hills that reflect the sun at sunset and create a dream like city below. Jaipur is my favorite city so far. It’s a lot less busier than Delhi and much more beautiful than Agra. On arrival we were greeted at the traffic lights by a little boy (nothing unusual for india). This little boy was different though because he was happy to take food instead of money. We gave him and his mum a banana each that we bought from a man earlier that day. As we drove off i looked back and saw them both smiling ecstatically as they ate their bananas. These are the types of things that satisfy the soul. Anyway, we arrived late in the afternoon so went straight to the hotel. It is a heritage building with big wooden doors and intricately decorated walls. It’s not like the other commercial hotels, this one is home like and the people here are genuinely lovely. We fell asleep early and started our sightseeing early in the morning. Our first stop was the Amber Fort. HOLY COW! Highlight of the trip so far. The fort is perched in the hills and is just massive. We drove to the top and when we walked in, we both smiled like children in a candy store. There were elephants walking through the main arena as authentic drums played from the top of a tower. Even cooler than that – we had free reign. We could walk up stairs, into dark hallways and down into hidden rooms. At one point matt and i found ourselves in a completely abandoned part of the fort. No one was around and we could hardly hear the thousands of tourists within the monument. If anyone asks – we did not pretend to be explorers of an ancient tomb, I swear.

The same day we got Amit to drop us in the city centre and pick us up 3 hours later. In that time we explored the Hawa Mahal and “junta munta” (Matt’s name for it but I can’t remember the actual pronunciation). We also walked the streets and bought our coloured powder for the Holi Festival – more about that later. We also navigated ourselves to LMB – a vegetarian restaurant recommended by lonely planet. We were stoked when we got there because it was the first place we found ourselves for food. It was delicious and cheap and ultra satisfying to be able to say WE found it.

We made our way back to Amit and drove to the Elephant Festival. The celebrations are held at the polo club in Jaipur and elephants are painted by their owners and paraded around the grounds for the spot as “best elephant”. The festival goes for 3 hours but there wasn’t as much involvement of the elephants as we thought. In fact, we made our way to watch the tug of war in anticipation of seeing elephants pull rope with their trunks only to be disappointed in finding out it was tug of war between humans. Boring! Been there done that. Matt and I did laugh that we thought it involved elephants because it’s actually quite a ridiculous concept.

At the elephant festival we found Nicola and Jacob (which we thought would be near impossible in the large crowds). We decided to all go to a place called the Peacock Rooftop Restaurant for dinner. It was nothing short of amazing! It was decorated with fairy lights and plants and chairs that looked like peacocks and had wheels! Ahhhhh the small things Oh and the food was awesome too.

If you are allergic to fun, scared of colours or disgusted by once in a lifetime opportunities – stop reading now. If none of the said circumstances apply to you, please, join us in our recap of one of the best festivals the world has to offer – Holi

Holi is held every year and celebrated around the country. It basically consists of smothering everyone in brightly coloured powders and squirting water from plastic guns. We didn’t know exactly how we would celebrate but when we got to the car we told Amit to take us to the city centre. As we drove Amit turned around and asked us if we wanted to go to his sisters house to celebrate holi. We were like HELL YEH but he didn’t understand so we gave him a few thumbs up and smiles as we slowly mouthed O K. None the less we ended up at his sisters house where she lives with her husband, husbands brothers and sisters, their partners, mother, father and all the children. This is normal for Indian families -but thank god I don’t have to live with my whole family for the rest of my life. I would slowly die inside. Maybe become a mute or live my life through a puppet I would call Gary. I love my family, but let’s be honest – I love my own space. Haha

Ok, so once we arrived at the house we “played holi”. The best part of Holi – everyone plays. The smallest child to the oldest man. It’s awesome! We smothered the children with pinks and yellows and smeared the oldies with greens and reds. The children squirted us with their guns and the adults poured water over our heads. As strangers walked past we exchanged “happy holi” as we swapped colors on each others faces. Matt and I wore white and planned to keep our tops as momento. Half way through the day matt realized my top was inside out. Now I’m more reminded that I can’t dress myself.

After the colors, we sat around eating snacks and fruit and drinking tea. I say snacks because i have no idea what they were and most of them made me want to vomit in my mouth. We ate them out of politeness and poor matt often had to finish my dregs. We put music on and danced and played cricket in the street. I sat with Diksha – the cutest little 3 year old girl – and showed her games on my iPad. She bloody loved it. She was very smart too because she wrote her whole name in my drawing app.

Before lunch the family offered us their showers. They were a tap with a bucket and jug. I stood there naked for a while thinking – what the heck do I do here. I ended up squatting under the tap as I tried to apply soap and face wash. I’m sure it would have been very amusing to watch. Diksha’s mum gave me a selection of clean clothes to wear. I chose some pink and gold pants and a beautifully sewn Punjabi top. I walked out of the room and the ladies did my hair and gave me a scarf and shoes. They were so lovely it was ridiculous. They gave Matt western clothes and frankly – he looked like an idiot. I definitely got the better end of the deal because they insisted we keep the clothes to remember them!

The family fed us a curry with rice and roti. By this time it was about 4 in the Arvo. We were so tired and ready to go. We told Amit we should go back to the hotel but the family wouldn’t let us. They insisted we sleep and have dinner with them. We were flattered but really wanted to go back to the hotel and relax. We are both too polite though and when they told us to watch the cricket we did. It was Australia versus Sri Lanka in Adelaide! I got a bit homesick and wanted to go so we pretended we had a Skype date with our family. We half expected them to shove us in front of the computer and offer us their Internet just so we could stay. Haha. It was hospitality to the max. Don’t worry – we eventually got out of there and spent the night on the roof eating chocolate and playing skip Bo.

Today we leave Jaipur and fly to Udaipur – a city surrounded by lakes. We have to say goodbye to Amit and the convenience of having a driver and hello to independence in India. Amit has become our friend. Though we struggle to converse, we think he is a sweet gentle boy and he thinks we are funny Aussies. When we are sightseeing he waits in the car and practices his english. When we come back he always has something he learnt to say to us. Once he told Matt “I am your biggest fan”, another time, after I lost my ring, he said he couldn’t sleep because he was sad about my ring. He always gives the children at the red lights some change and goes far beyond anyone else to make sure we are happy. We will definitely give him a good tip and be sad to say goodbye.

On that note, we better pack and get ready for our flight.

Liv

item.title: The Streets of Manila from Inside a Car – Part 2
item.dc:creator: bensonkua
item.description: A continuation of my previous post about taking pictures of the street from inside a car. I managed to find some more pictures that I liked and decided to show them off here in the blog. Enjoy! “A classic car stuck in traffic (well, us too…) on the Southern Luzon Expressway – I wonder if it [...]
item.content:encoded:
A continuation of my previous post about taking pictures of the street from inside a car. I managed to find some more pictures that I liked and decided to show them off here in the blog. Enjoy!

“A classic car stuck in traffic (well, us too…) on the Southern Luzon Expressway – I wonder if it had air-conditioning….”

“Caution”

“Metro-aide – Public street cleaners (Must be a really tough job in the hot and humid Philippine weather)”

“The Doorman”

“OK, he was CLEARLY blocking the driveway!”

“Umm…. guys, I think we have found Superman’s secret hideout!!!”

“I can’t imagine this to be a very comfortable position to sleep in…”

“Tricycles”

“Early morning traffic (although this was still pretty tame)”

“Polluter – Who knew that the little motorcycle engine could spew so much smoke!? He needs to get that checked out!”

item.title: Great Horned Owl chicks grow and fledge in Golden Gate Park
item.dc:creator: gnevill
item.description: A report of a Great Horned Owl nest in Golden Gate Park prompted three visits over the past 6 weeks.  My first visit on Feb 5, 2012 found two chicks and the mother in a very large pine tree. As always, click on the image to enlarge it. Those days’ shots can be seen at [...]
item.content:encoded:
A report of a Great Horned Owl nest in Golden Gate Park prompted three visits over the past 6 weeks.  My first visit on Feb 5, 2012 found two chicks and the mother in a very large pine tree. As always, click on the image to enlarge it.

Those days’ shots can be seen at this link

Then on Feb 19, I returned and found the chicks grown quite a bit…

That days’ shots can be seen at this link.

And then on March 10, I came back to find both chicks had fledged, I found them with one of the adults in another tree some 50 yards away.

a better view of one of them…

Here it is cleaning its beak on a tree branch…

The two fledglings together…

Not too far away in the park, the Great Blue Herons are nesting at Stow Lake. Here is one about to settle down in its nest by the boat house.

I’ll leave you with a shot of a Song Sparrow taken at the lake that day, it was singing, looking for a mate. Spring will soon be here.

And you can find the complete set of photos for the owls from this weekend at this link.

Thanks for looking.

Regards,

Glenn Nevill


Filed under: biology, birdwatching, conservation, eco-tourism, environment, Golden Gate Park, Great Blue Heron, inspiration, nature, owls, personal growth, photography, Raptors, Song Sparrow Tagged: Golden Gate Park, Great Blue Heron, Great Horned Owls, Song Sparrow

item.title: X Marks The Spot
item.dc:creator: aparisi13
item.description: I love libraries…well, I love the idea of libraries. Whenever I go to a new library, I always have the same hope that the inside will resemble the Venetian library that was featured in Indiana Jones and The Last Crusade…minus all of the rats and fire. I hold my breath with the excitement that white [...]
item.content:encoded:
I love libraries…well, I love the idea of libraries. Whenever I go to a new library, I always have the same hope that the inside will resemble the Venetian library that was featured in Indiana Jones and The Last Crusade…minus all of the rats and fire. I hold my breath with the excitement that white marble floors and painted ceilings can arouse. I long for the smell of worn leather bindings and yellowing parchment. When I go to a library, I want to literally be transported to a different era, when people had loads of money to decorate buildings from floor to ceiling with knick knacks made of solid gold. I am always disappointed when faced with the fluorescently lit reality that has been every library I have ever had the misfortune to visit…and yet my quest for the perfect library continues, much as Indiana’s search for the holy grail.

…

Until yesterday…

Roswell P. Flower Memorial Library • Watertown, NY

Yesterday, while feeling particularly adventurous, I decided to head over to check out Watertown’s local library, The Roswell P. Flower Memorial Library. I felt a catch in my chest as I passed two ferocious white marble lions guarding the front entrance. I felt a skip of my heart as my eyes rested on the golden zodiac symbols that adorn the floor. I blacked out for a moment as I gazed upon ceilings decorated with ornate paintings, gold leaf and stained glass. I may have even let out a small, quiet squeal of delight as I danced across the lobby floor. I spent about an hour or so walking from room to room taking photographs and bothering the patrons who were trying to read.

This has become my new favorite spot to shoot indoor photos, fight off cabin fever and combat the winter blues (in the event that winter ever shows up…I’m not complaining). If you would like to learn more about the Roswell P. Flower Memorial Library, visit their website: http://www.flowermemoriallibrary.org/
